awd_titl_txt: Rural Ventures: Mineral Exploration and Economic Life
awd_abstract_narration:
Efforts to regulate expert communications within venture capital markets have been studied for their effects on prospective investors, but not for their impacts on individuals living near the sites where market activities originate. This research addresses this gap by examining how relationships between mining industry experts and rural residents take shape around speculative projects during periods of market collapse. Throughout North America, new corporate outreach strategies and environmental risk assessment regulations have caused mining companies to engage with rural communities ever further in advance of actual mining activity. This research examines the social consequences of these shifts in the context of a recent “boom” and subsequent “bust” affecting several towns and Indigenous reservations. In 2011, a spectacular rise and fall in global market prices for rare earth elements drew half a dozen small companies to the region to conduct geological analysis and local promotion campaigns. While none of the prospects identified became producing mines, exploration experts have continued to visit the region to encourage residents to sustain their hopes that new mines will eventually be constructed. This research will generate new insights into how residents of rural communities come to participate in globalizing knowledge economies by examining how local conversations about mineral exploration, venture finance, and regional economic uncertainty increasingly highlight the individual agency and mobility.

This project contributes to analyses of the roles that experts and expert knowledge play in shaping contemporary rural life by examining how resident-expert relationships take shape around promised projects that may never be realized. The project addresses two main questions: (1) How do new forms of financial and other technical information shape how rural residents understand the “failure” of exploratory projects and their potential for future renewal? (2) How have venture capitalism and the financialization of resource development planning altered conversations about regional futures and economic life? Data come from interviews and observations of everyday life during prolonged lulls in exploration activity. Analysis will focus on how references to exploratory projects emerge in residents’ encounters with political leaders, geologists, and financial experts as each group speculates about delays and discusses other potential futures for regional landscapes. Building on ethnographic engagements with Indigenous corporations and governance groups working to re-shape resource economies, the project also examines how Indigenous groups with diverse political and economic ambitions are working to frame these deferrals alongside longstanding sovereignty goals and other collective prerogatives. Overall, the project explains how venture market-focused regulatory processes have changed the ways experts active in rural areas understand the ethical demands of their work, and how these processes affect residents’ sense of their own futures amid profound economic and ecological changes.

This project is jointly funded by Science and Technology Studies and Cultural Anthroplogy in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
“Rural Ventures” explores how the proliferation of new kinds of scientific research – and new forms of social and economic uncertainty – around proposed mining developments have changed the ways different workers see themselves contributing to shared projects and establishing new senses of community in today’s American Mountain West. In recent years, public and private investments in “critical minerals” development projects have increased dramatically in response to calls for decarbonizing energy transitions and decreased reliance on globally distributed manufacturing supply chains. Numerous early-stage mineral exploration projects focused on cobalt, nickel, lithium, rare earth elements, and other materials required for the production of electric car batteries have been proposed, and while very few mines have reached production, a growing number of these projects increasingly depend on funding sources framed around collaborative research and economic diversification initiatives. These dependencies have required a diverse range of people to work together to develop plausible plans to develop “downstream” industries related to battery materials production and assembly, including minerals processing plants, battery testing laboratories, and other facilities. While news coverage of these developments has rapidly expanded, particularly since January 2025, as major shifts in international diplomatic strategies have been justified as efforts to secure sources of rare earths and other minerals, the experiences of the many different rural residents expected to work together to produce these transitions remains poorly understood.

Through ethnographic studies of emergent collaborative arrangements in Idaho, “Rural Ventures” offers a nuanced understanding of the ways the people brought together through these arrangements theorize and respond to the many different kinds of uncertainties affecting their respective industries and everyday lives. The project shows how collaborations around critical minerals generate intersections between institutional worlds and spaces of discussion characterized by dramatically different planning timelines, experiences of social mobility, conceptualizations of success, and senses of place. The publications that have been produced or are under development as a result of this research show how the proliferation of new forms of uncertainty have generated frustration, political alienation, and especially a sense of rootlessness for workers attempting to build lives and careers in rural areas. The project also demonstrates the growing importance of understanding these experiences in light of radically disruptive global policy developments that have recently added new and even greater uncertainties both to international critical minerals trade agreements and to experts’ experiences of migration in the US and in other countries – countries to which many US-based critical minerals experts (and experts-in-training) are now seeking to migrate in light of protectionist trade policies, sudden losses of research grants, and hostile and capricious immigration policy actions. “Rural Ventures” offers a wide range of case studies to show how energy transitions and economic diversification projects are intertwined with demographic transformations in the America Mountain West. The transformations involve people who have lived in specific places for many generations, as well as others who are on the move. For instance, this project shows how “brain drain” – both from rural to urban areas in the US, but increasingly also away from the US to other countries – has increasingly become a multi-dimensional phenomenon, as prospective workers assess new and old locales based on specific economic opportunities, general industry trends, and social and political climates, all of which are changing simultaneously in the places where this research was conducted.

Overall, “Rural Ventures” highlights a paradox affecting predominant understandings of the roles that actual people will play in bringing about technological advancement and economic change. The contemporary American mining and high-tech manufacturing industries have been designed to prioritize flexibility over institutional continuity and sustained investment in particular locales, and many people who work in or live near these industries have experienced dramatically more risk and insecurity as a result. This is the primary reason that, despite the clear need to systematically re-develop these industries in just and inclusive ways for different communities throughout the Mountain West, including those still managing the toxic legacies and social fallout of earlier periods of extraction, actually doing so remains extremely challenging. Despite the high visibility and revolutionary promise associated with new collaborative arrangements, the risks associated with future development remain highly individualized, and participants’ sense that they are meaningfully contributing to collective projects remains tenuous.
